page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Supreme Council of the Armed Forces

rev.diff:
Line 161: Line 161:
==August==
==August==
  +
{{External media
  +
| video1 = {{YouTube|kLkIK2ZREsk|Salma el Daly's testimony about the Ramadan Iftar}}
  +
| video2 = {{YouTube|SoOkvHMHZus|Salma Said's testimony about the Ramadan Iftar}}
  +
}}
On first August, the first day of [[Ramadan]], Egyptian soldiers clashed with protesters in Tahrir Square, tearing down tents the activists have used for the sit-in that where hundreds of protesters have been sleeping in the square since July 8.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hassieb |first=Ingy |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle-east/egypts-military-police-break-up-tahrir-square-sit-in/2011/08/01/gIQAnvPOnI_story.html |title=Egyptâs military police forcibly break up Tahrir Square sit-in |publisher=The Washington Post |date= |accessdate=2011-08-02}}</ref> Egyptian forces swinging electrified batons and shouting the battle cry "'''God is great'''" yesterday swiftly chased off dozens of activists who had refused to end four weeks of renewed protests at [[Tahrir Square]] to pressure the countryâs transitional military rulers. Hundreds of riot police backed by armored vehicles and soldiers moved in to tear down the camp of dozens of tents after a group of holdout activists - some of them relatives of people killed in the uprising that toppled [[Hosni Mubarak]] in February - refused pleas over loudspeakers to go home. Some in the crowd hurled stones at the police.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.boston.com/2011-08-02/news/29843122_1_ammar-ali-hassan-tahrir-square-hosni-mubarak |title=Soldiers clear Tahrir Square to end latest protests - Boston.com |publisher=Articles.boston.com |date=2011-08-02 |accessdate=2011-08-06}}</ref> Protesters' rights groups said that the military police detained 66 people in the process.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2011/08/02/Marches-planned-to-free-Egypt-protesters/UPI-56181312292823/ |title=Marches planned to free Egypt protesters |publisher=UPI.com |date= |accessdate=2011-08-06}}</ref> The removal of the Tahrir sit-in was a calculated political move. Average citizens had been growing weary of the lack of mobility in the central square, so when the military showed up on early Monday afternoon they were met with cheers. Most Egyptians support the militaryâs actions.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mayton |first=Joseph |url=http://www.dawn.com/2011/08/03/egypt%E2%80%99s-liberals-push-limits-as-mubarak-trial-gets-under-way.html |title=Egyptâs liberals push limits as Mubarak trial gets under way |publisher=Dawn.Com |date= |accessdate=2011-08-06}}</ref>
On first August, the first day of [[Ramadan]], Egyptian soldiers clashed with protesters in Tahrir Square, tearing down tents the activists have used for the sit-in that where hundreds of protesters have been sleeping in the square since July 8.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hassieb |first=Ingy |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle-east/egypts-military-police-break-up-tahrir-square-sit-in/2011/08/01/gIQAnvPOnI_story.html |title=Egyptâs military police forcibly break up Tahrir Square sit-in |publisher=The Washington Post |date= |accessdate=2011-08-02}}</ref> Egyptian forces swinging electrified batons and shouting the battle cry "'''God is great'''" yesterday swiftly chased off dozens of activists who had refused to end four weeks of renewed protests at [[Tahrir Square]] to pressure the countryâs transitional military rulers. Hundreds of riot police backed by armored vehicles and soldiers moved in to tear down the camp of dozens of tents after a group of holdout activists - some of them relatives of people killed in the uprising that toppled [[Hosni Mubarak]] in February - refused pleas over loudspeakers to go home. Some in the crowd hurled stones at the police.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.boston.com/2011-08-02/news/29843122_1_ammar-ali-hassan-tahrir-square-hosni-mubarak |title=Soldiers clear Tahrir Square to end latest protests - Boston.com |publisher=Articles.boston.com |date=2011-08-02 |accessdate=2011-08-06}}</ref> Protesters' rights groups said that the military police detained 66 people in the process.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2011/08/02/Marches-planned-to-free-Egypt-protesters/UPI-56181312292823/ |title=Marches planned to free Egypt protesters |publisher=UPI.com |date= |accessdate=2011-08-06}}</ref> The removal of the Tahrir sit-in was a calculated political move. Average citizens had been growing weary of the lack of mobility in the central square, so when the military showed up on early Monday afternoon they were met with cheers. Most Egyptians support the militaryâs actions.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mayton |first=Joseph |url=http://www.dawn.com/2011/08/03/egypt%E2%80%99s-liberals-push-limits-as-mubarak-trial-gets-under-way.html |title=Egyptâs liberals push limits as Mubarak trial gets under way |publisher=Dawn.Com |date= |accessdate=2011-08-06}}</ref>
